lives underground biding their time
until they surface in huge noisy
red-eyed swarms when they emerge the
number in the billions taking over
entire forests and suburbs causing car
accidents and ruining more picnics and

about they're so weird and appear so
rarely that we still don't understand

they've managed to turn a lazy
low-profile lifestyle into one of
Earth's greatest evolutionary success
stories and that coming sometimes people
mistake locusts for cicadas because
locusts are also big noisy summer bugs
but cicadas are their own family of
plants sucking insects that includes
more than 2,000 species some species
known as annual cicadas live underground
for just two to eight years and can be
found all over the world different
populations of these species appear at
different times so you might run across
them in any given summer but what
America is bracing for right now is
another kind periodical cicadas they are
only found in the United States and they
emerge once every 13 or 17 years and
unlike annual cicadas these species
consist of just a few but enormous
populations called brood so broods life
cycles are synchronized so that they all
emerge at the same time there are 15
known broods each assigned a number and
this month brood - also known as the
East Coast brood is going to emerge 17
years after they were born back in 1996
brood - hatched from their eggs as
nymphs basically miniature versions of
their adult cells after hanging out for
a few weeks that summer may be taken in
the Olympics in Atlanta talking about
whether Bill Clinton would be reelected
the nymphs dug 30 centimetres or so into
the soil and got comfortable for the
next 17 years they just sucked nutrients
from nearby
roots and matured very very slowly in
isolation basically it was like puberty
except in a burrow instead of a bedroom
plastered with one direction posters and
with root juice to eat instead of pizza
bagels now after all those years later
this month a hormone trigger will snap
the cicadas out of their torpor he'll
crawl to the surface quickly go through
one final molt to emerge as adults then
there does two things left to do have
some sex and die males cluster in trees
and make loud buzzing mating calls in
unison known politely as choruses these
obnoxious love songs have been measured
at more than a hundred decibels louder
than a lawnmower or motorcycle engine
but they do the trick
females respond and after mating they
lay their eggs on a low-lying branch
before both adults die in about four
weeks the eggs will hatch and the whole
thing starts over again now that might
all sound kind of fruitless but the fact
is the cicada life cycle is perfectly
suited to doing the two and only two
things that evolution demands of us
surviving and reproducing first of all
cicadas spend 98% of their lives
underground protected from the elements
and predators which is partly why they
live longer than any other insect North
America but even more awesome is how
cicadas have harnessed the power of the
swarm broods can be so huge that as many
as 1.5 million individuals can occupy a
single acre so even though the bugs
themselves are big and slow the brood
can survive easily because there are
just too many of them to eat this little
evolutionary trick is known as predator
satiation predators can't wipe you out
when they're already full they just
don't have room inside of them in fact
scientists have found that cicadas
numbers are so overwhelming that they
can actually manipulate the populations
of the birds that eat them - the cicadas
advantage in 2012 a USDA study found
that birds like cuckoos and woodpeckers
experienced huge spikes in numbers after
cicadas emerge but the spikes are so big
that three years later the populations
crash just in time for the next brood to
emerge the trick for the cicada is to
show up when the bird populations are at
their smallest I mean if you're only
